motion-activated light using PIR sensor and transistor BC547. Perfect for home automation projects.",category:"Basic Electronics",difficulty:"Beginner",duration:"30 mins",image:"https://images.pexels.com/photos/356056/pexels-photo-356056.jpeg?auto=compress&cs=tinysrgb&w=400",views:1250,downloads:89,components:["PIR Motion Sensor","BC547 Transistor","LED (5mm)","220 Resistor","10k Resistor","9V Battery","Breadboard","Jumper Wires"],youtubeId:"dQw4w9WgXcQ",schematic:"https://images.pexels.com/photos/163064/play-stone-network-networked-interactive-163064.jpeg?auto=compress&cs=tinysrgb&w=600",code:`// Motion Sensor Light Code
const int pirPin = 2;
const int ledPin = 13;

void setup() {
  pinMode(pirPin, INPUT);
  pinMode(ledPin, OUTPUT);
  Serial.begin(9600);
}

void loop() {
  int motion = digitalRead(pirPin);
  
  if (motion == HIGH) {
    digitalWrite(ledPin, HIGH);
    Serial.println("Motion detected!");
    delay(5000); // Keep light on for 5 seconds
  } else {
    digitalWrite(ledPin, LOW);
  }
  
  delay(100);
}`,instructions:["Connect PIR sensor VCC to 5V and GND to ground","Connect PIR output to digital pin 2","Connect BC547 base to pin 2 through 10k resistor","Connect LED to collector through 220 resistor","Connect emitter to ground","Upload code and test with motion"]},{id:"2",title:"Clap Switch using 555 Timer",description:"Build a sound-activated switch that responds to clapping sounds using the versatile 555 timer IC in bistable mode.",category:"Arduino",difficulty:"Intermediate",duration:"45 mins",image:"https://images.pexels.com/photos/442150/pexels-photo-442150.jpeg?auto=compress&cs=tinysrgb&w=400",views:980,downloads:67,components:["555 Timer IC","Condenser Microphone","BC547 Transistor","LED","Resistors (various)","Capacitors","Relay Module","Breadboard"],youtubeId:"dQw4w9WgXcQ",schematic:"https://images.pexels.com/photos/163064/play-stone-network-networked-interactive-163064.jpeg?auto=compress&cs=tinysrgb&w=600",code:`// Clap Switch Arduino Code
const int micPin = A0;
const int ledPin = 13;
const int relayPin = 7;

bool lightState = false;
int threshold = 100;

void setup() {
  pinMode(ledPin, OUTPUT);
  pinMode(relayPin, OUTPUT);
  Serial.begin(9600);
}

void loop() {
  int soundLevel = analogRead(micPin);
  
  if (soundLevel > threshold) {
    lightState = !lightState;
    digitalWrite(ledPin, lightState);
    digitalWrite(relayPin, lightState);
    
    Serial.println(lightState ? "Light ON" : "Light OFF");
    delay(1000); // Debounce delay
  }
  
  delay(50);
}`,instructions:["Build the 555 timer circuit in bistable mode","Connect microphone to amplification circuit","Wire the output to control relay","Test sensitivity with sound input","Adjust threshold for optimal response","Connect load device through relay"]},{id:"3",title:"ESP32 Web Server LED Control",description:"Control LEDs wirelessly through a web interface using ESP32. #include <WebServer.h>

const char* ssid = "YourWiFiSSID";
const char* password = "YourPassword";

WebServer server(80);

const int redLED = 2;
const int greenLED = 4;
const int blueLED = 5;

void setup() {
  Serial.begin(115200);
  
  pinMode(redLED, OUTPUT);
  pinMode(greenLED, OUTPUT);
  pinMode(blueLED, OUTPUT);
  
  WiFi.begin(ssid, password);
  while (WiFi.status() != WL_CONNECTED) {
    delay(1000);
    Serial.println("Connecting to WiFi...");
  }
  
  Serial.println("WiFi connected!");
  Serial.println(WiFi.localIP());
  
  server.on("/", handleRoot);
  server.on("/red/on", [](){digitalWrite(redLED, HIGH); server.send(200, "text/plain", "Red LED ON");});
  server.on("/red/off", [](){digitalWrite(redLED, LOW); server.send(200, "text/plain", "Red LED OFF");});
  
  server.begin();
}

void loop() {
  server.handleClient();
}

void handleRoot() {
  String html = "<html><body><h1>ESP32 LED Control</h1>";
  html += "<p><a href='/red/on'>Turn Red LED ON</a></p>";
  html += "<p><a href='/red/off'>Turn Red LED OFF</a></p>";
  html += "</body></html>";
  server.send(200, "text/html", html);
}`,instructions:["Connect LEDs to GPIO pins 2, 4, and 5","Add 220 resistors in series with each LED","Install ESP32 board package in Arduino IDE","Update WiFi credentials in code","Upload code to ESP32","Access web interface using ESP32 IP address"]},{id:"4",title:"Arduino Temperature Monitor with LCD",description:"Display real-time temperature and humidity readings on an LCD screen using DHT22 sensor and Arduino.",category:"Arduino",difficulty:"Beginner",duration:"40 mins",image:"https://images.pexels.com/photos/276514/pexels-photo-276514.jpeg?auto=compress&cs=tinysrgb&w=400",views:2100,downloads:156,components:["Arduino Uno","DHT22 Temperature Sensor","16x2 LCD Display","10k Potentiometer","Breadboard","Jumper Wires"],youtubeId:"dQw4w9WgXcQ",schematic:"https://images.pexels.com/photos/163064/play-stone-network-networked-interactive-163064.jpeg?auto=compress&cs=tinysrgb&w=600",code:`#include <LiquidCrystal.h>
#include <DHT.h>

#define DHTPIN 2
#define DHTTYPE DHT22

DHT dht(DHTPIN, DHTTYPE);
LiquidCrystal lcd(12, 11, 5, 4, 3, 2);

void setup() {
  lcd.begin(16, 2);
  dht.begin();
  lcd.print("Temp & Humidity");
  lcd.setCursor(0, 1);
  lcd.print("Monitor Starting");
  delay(2000);
  lcd.clear();
}

void loop() {
  float temperature = dht.readTemperature();
  float humidity = dht.readHumidity();
  
  if (isnan(temperature) || isnan(humidity)) {
    lcd.clear();
    lcd.print("Sensor Error!");
    return;
  }
  
  lcd.setCursor(0, 0);
  lcd.print("Temp: ");
  lcd.print(temperature);
  lcd.print("C");
  
  lcd.setCursor(0, 1);
  lcd.print("Humidity: ");
  lcd.print(humidity);
  lcd.print("%");
  
  delay(2000);
}`,instructions:["Wire LCD display to Arduino (pins 12,11,5,4,3,2)","Connect DHT22 sensor to digital pin 2","Add potentiometer for LCD contrast control","Install DHT and LiquidCrystal libraries","Upload code and verify sensor readings","Calibrate display contrast if needed"]},{id:"5",title:"IoT Plant Watering System",description:"Automated plant care system using soil moisture sensor, water pump, and ESP32 with mobile app control.",category:"IoT",difficulty:"Advanced",duration:"120 mins",image:"https://images.pexels.com/photos/1301856/pexels-photo-1301856.jpeg?auto=compress&cs=tinysrgb&w=400",views:1890,downloads:98,components:["ESP32 Board","Soil Moisture Sensor","Water Pump (5V)","Relay Module","DHT22 Sensor","OLED Display","Tubing and Container"],youtubeId:"dQw4w9WgXcQ",schematic:"https://images.pexels.com/photos/163064/play-stone-network-networked-interactive-163064.jpeg?auto=compress&cs=tinysrgb&w=600",code:`#include <WiFi.h>
#include <BlynkSimpleEsp32.h>
#include <DHT.h>

#define DHTPIN 4
#define DHTTYPE DHT22
#define SOIL_PIN A0
#define PUMP_PIN 2
#define RELAY_PIN 5

DHT dht(DHTPIN, DHTTYPE);

char auth[] = "YourBlynkToken";
char ssid[] = "YourWiFi";
char pass[] = "YourPassword";

BlynkTimer timer;

void setup() {
  Serial.begin(115200);
  pinMode(PUMP_PIN, OUTPUT);
  pinMode(RELAY_PIN, OUTPUT);
  
  dht.begin();
  Blynk.begin(auth, ssid, pass);
  
  timer.setInterval(10000L, sendSensorData);
  timer.setInterval(60000L, checkSoilMoisture);
}

void loop() {
  Blynk.run();
  timer.run();
}

void sendSensorData() {
  float temp = dht.readTemperature();
  float humidity = dht.readHumidity();
  int soilMoisture = analogRead(SOIL_PIN);
  
  Blynk.virtualWrite(V1, temp);
  Blynk.virtualWrite(V2, humidity);
  Blynk.virtualWrite(V3, soilMoisture);
}

void checkSoilMoisture() {
  int moisture = analogRead(SOIL_PIN);
  if (moisture < 300) { // Dry soil threshold
    digitalWrite(RELAY_PIN, HIGH);
    delay(5000); // Water for 5 seconds
    digitalWrite(RELAY_PIN, LOW);
    Blynk.notify("Plant watered automatically!");
  }
}

BLYNK_WRITE(V4) {
  if (param.asInt() == 1) {
    digitalWrite(RELAY_PIN, HIGH);
    delay(3000);
    digitalWrite(RELAY_PIN, LOW);
  }
}`,instructions:["Set up Blynk account and create new project","Connect soil moisture sensor to analog pin","Wire relay module to control water pump","Install required libraries in Arduino IDE","Configure Blynk app with widgets","Test automatic and manual watering modes","Set up notifications for plant care reminders"]},{id:"6",title:"LED Traffic Light Controller",description:"Simulate a realistic traffic light system with timing controls and pedestrian crossing features using Arduino.",category:"Basic Electronics",difficulty:"Beginner",duration:"35 mins",image:"https://images.pexels.com/photos/442579/pexels-photo-442579.jpeg?auto=compress&cs=tinysrgb&w=400",views:1456,downloads:78,components:["Arduino Uno","Red LED (3x)","Yellow LED (3x)","Green LED (3x)","220 Resistors (9x)","Breadboard","Jumper Wires"],youtubeId:"dQw4w9WgXcQ",schematic:"https://images.pexels.com/photos/163064/play-stone-network-networked-interactive-163064.jpeg?auto=compress&cs=tinysrgb&w=600",code:`// Traffic Light Controller
const int redLight1 = 2;
const int yellowLight1 = 3;
const int greenLight1 = 4;

const int redLight2 = 5;
const int yellowLight2 = 6;
const int greenLight2 = 7;

void setup() {
  pinMode(redLight1, OUTPUT);
  pinMode(yellowLight1, OUTPUT);
  pinMode(greenLight1, OUTPUT);
  pinMode(redLight2, OUTPUT);
  pinMode(yellowLight2, OUTPUT);
  pinMode(greenLight2, OUTPUT);
}

void loop() {
  // Direction 1: Green, Direction 2: Red
  digitalWrite(greenLight1, HIGH);
  digitalWrite(redLight2, HIGH);
  delay(5000);
  
  // Direction 1: Yellow, Direction 2: Red
  digitalWrite(greenLight1, LOW);
  digitalWrite(yellowLight1, HIGH);
  delay(2000);
  
  // Direction 1: Red, Direction 2: Red (all stop)
  digitalWrite(yellowLight1, LOW);
  digitalWrite(redLight1, HIGH);
  delay(1000);
  
  // Direction 1: Red, Direction 2: Green
  digitalWrite(redLight2, LOW);
  digitalWrite(greenLight2, HIGH);
  delay(5000);
  
  // Direction 1: Red, Direction 2: Yellow
  digitalWrite(greenLight2, LOW);
  digitalWrite(yellowLight2, HIGH);
  delay(2000);
  
  // All Red before cycle repeats
  digitalWrite(yellowLight2, LOW);
  digitalWrite(redLight2, HIGH);
  delay(1000);
  digitalWrite(redLight1, LOW);
}`,instructions:["Connect LEDs to digital pins 2-7 with resistors","Organize LEDs to represent two traffic directions","Upload the traffic light control code","Test the timing sequence","Adjust delays for different timing needs","Add pedestrian button for manual override"]}],Oh=["All","Arduino","ESP32","IoT","Basic Electronics","Sensors","Robotics"],zh=["All","Beginner","Intermediate","Advanced"],wd=[{id:"1",title:"Understanding Resistors: The Foundation of Electronics",excerpt:"Learn everything about resistors - from color codes to power ratings and practical applications in electronic circuits.",category:"Basic Electronics",readTime:"8 min read",image:"https://images.pexels.com/photos/163064/play-stone-network-networked-interactive-163064.jpeg?auto=compress&cs=tinysrgb&w=400",publishDate:"2024-01-15",content:`
# Understanding Resistors: The Foundation of Electronics

Resistors are one of the most fundamental components in electronics. They control the flow of electric current in a circuit by providing resistance.

## What is a Resistor?

A resistor is a passive electrical component that implements electrical resistance as a circuit element. In electronic circuits, resistors are used to reduce current flow, adjust signal levels, divide voltages, bias active elements, and terminate transmission lines.

## Types of Resistors

### Fixed Resistors
- Carbon composition resistors
- Carbon film resistors  
- Metal film resistors
- Wire wound resistors

### Variable Resistors
- Potentiometers
- Rheostats
- Trimmers

## Resistor Color Code

The resistor color code is a system used to indicate the resistance value and tolerance of resistors:

| Color | Digit | Multiplier | Tolerance |
|-------|-------|------------|-----------|
| Black | 0 | 1 | - |
| Brown | 1 | 10 | 1% |
| Red | 2 | 100 | 2% |
| Orange | 3 | 1,000 | - |
| Yellow | 4 | 10,000 | - |
| Green | 5 | 100,000 | 0.5% |
| Blue | 6 | 1,000,000 | 0.25% |
| Violet | 7 | 10,000,000 | 0.1% |
| Gray | 8 | - | 0.05% |
| White | 9 | - | - |
| Gold | - | 0.1 | 5% |
| Silver | - | 0.01 | 10% |

## Power Rating

Resistors have power ratings that indicate how much power they can safely dissipate as heat. Common power ratings include:
- 1/8 watt (0.125W)
- 1/4 watt (0.25W)  
- 1/2 watt (0.5W)
- 1 watt
- 2 watts and higher

## Practical Applications

1. **Current Limiting**: Protecting LEDs and other components
2. **Voltage Division**: Creating reference voltages
3. **Pull-up/Pull-down**: Digital circuit applications
4. **Biasing**: Setting operating points for transistors
5. **Filtering**: RC time constants in filters

## Ohm's Law and Resistors

Ohm's Law is fundamental when working with resistors:
- V = I  R (Voltage = Current  Resistance)
- P = V / R (Power = Voltage / Resistance)
- P = I  R (Power = Current  Resistance)

## Series and Parallel Combinations

### Series Resistors
Total resistance = R1 + R2 + R3 + ...

### Parallel Resistors  
1/Total resistance = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3 + ...

## Choosing the Right Resistor

When selecting resistors for your projects, consider:
1. Resistance value
2. Power rating
3. Tolerance
4. Temperature coefficient
5. Package size
6. Cost

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

- Using resistors with insufficient power ratings
- Misreading color codes
- Not considering tolerance in precision circuits
- Using variable resistors where fixed values are needed

Understanding resistors is crucial for any electronics enthusiast. They form the backbone of most electronic circuits and mastering their use will significantly improve your project success rate.
    `},{id:"2",title:"Getting Started with Arduino IDE: Complete Setup Guide",excerpt:"Step-by-step guide to install, configure, and use Arduino IDE for your electronics projects. Perfect for beginners.",category:"Arduino",readTime:"12 min read",image:"https://images.pexels.com/photos/442150/pexels-photo-442150.jpeg?auto=compress&cs=tinysrgb&w=400",publishDate:"2024-01-10",content:`
# Getting Started with Arduino IDE: Complete Setup Guide

The Arduino Integrated Development Environment (IDE) is the primary tool for programming Arduino microcontrollers. This comprehensive guide will help you get started.

## What is Arduino IDE?

Arduino IDE is a cross-platform application written in Java that provides a simple interface for writing, compiling, and uploading code to Arduino boards.

## Installation Process

### Windows
1. Download Arduino IDE from arduino.cc
2. Run the installer executable
3. Follow the installation wizard
4. Connect your Arduino board via USB

### macOS
1. Download the Arduino IDE DMG file
2. Drag the Arduino IDE to Applications folder
3. Install any required drivers
4. Launch the application

### Linux
1. Download the Linux version
2. Extract the archive
3. Run the install script
4. Add user to dialout group for USB permissions

## Interface Overview

### Main Components
- **Menu Bar**: File, Edit, Sketch, Tools, Help
- **Toolbar**: Quick access buttons
- **Editor**: Where you write your code
- **Message Area**: Compilation messages
- **Text Console**: Detailed output and errors

### Key Buttons
- **Verify**: Compiles your code
- **Upload**: Uploads code to Arduino
- **Serial Monitor**: View serial communication

## Board Configuration

1. Select your board: Tools  Board
2. Choose the correct port: Tools  Port
3. Verify the programmer setting

## Writing Your First Sketch

\`\`\`cpp
void setup() {
  // Initialize digital pin LED_BUILTIN as an output
  pinMode(LED_BUILTIN, OUTPUT);
}

void loop() {
  digitalWrite(LED_BUILTIN, HIGH);   // Turn LED on
  delay(1000);                       // Wait 1 second
  digitalWrite(LED_BUILTIN, LOW);    // Turn LED off
  delay(1000);                       // Wait 1 second
}
\`\`\`

## Essential Features

### Library Manager
- Tools  Manage Libraries
- Search and install libraries
- Keep libraries updated

### Serial Monitor
- View output from Serial.print()
- Send data to Arduino
- Essential for debugging

### Serial Plotter
- Visualize numerical data
- Great for sensor readings
- Real-time plotting

## Keyboard Shortcuts

| Action | Windows/Linux | macOS |
|--------|---------------|--------|
| Verify | Ctrl+R | Cmd+R |
| Upload | Ctrl+U | Cmd+U |
| New | Ctrl+N | Cmd+N |
| Open | Ctrl+O | Cmd+O |
| Save | Ctrl+S | Cmd+S |

## Preferences and Settings

### Important Settings
- Sketchbook location
- Editor font size
- Auto-format
- Line numbers
- Code folding

### Additional Board Support
- File  Preferences
- Additional Board Manager URLs
- Tools  Board  Board Manager

## Troubleshooting Common Issues

### Upload Problems
- Check board selection
- Verify correct port
- Ensure drivers are installed
- Try different USB cable

### Compilation Errors
- Check syntax carefully
- Verify library installation
- Look for missing semicolons
- Check variable declarations

### Serial Monitor Issues
- Set correct baud rate
- Close other serial applications
- Check serial port permissions

## Advanced Features

### Tabs and Multiple Files
- Organize large projects
- Create header files
- Use tabs for different functions

### Sketch Data Folder
- Store data files
- Upload files to SPIFFS
- Organize project resources

## Best Practices

1. **Code Organization**
   - Use meaningful variable names
   - Add comments to explain logic
   - Break complex code into functions

2. **Version Control**
   - Use Git for project management
   - Regular commits and backups
   - Document changes

3. **Testing**
   - Test code incrementally
   - Use Serial.print() for debugging
   - Validate inputs and outputs

## Useful Extensions

### Third-party IDEs
- PlatformIO
- Visual Studio Code with Arduino extension
- Eclipse Arduino IDE

### Online Alternatives
- Arduino Web Editor
- Tinkercad Circuits
- Wokwi Simulator

## Next Steps

Once you're comfortable with Arduino IDE:
1. Explore advanced programming concepts
2. Learn about different Arduino boards
3. Experiment with sensors and actuators
4. Join the Arduino community

The Arduino IDE is your gateway to the world of microcontroller programming. Take time to familiarize yourself with its features, and don't hesitate to experiment with different settings to find what works best for your workflow.
    `},{id:"3",title:"ESP32 vs Arduino: Which Microcontroller Should You Choose?",excerpt:"Comprehensive comparison between ESP32 and Arduino boards to help you choose the right platform for your next project.",category:"Comparison",readTime:"10 min read",image:"https://images.pexels.com/photos/356043/pexels-photo-356043.jpeg?auto=compress&cs=tinysrgb&w=400",publishDate:"2024-01-05",content:`
# ESP32 vs Arduino: Which Microcontroller Should You Choose?

Choosing between ESP32 and Arduino can be challenging for both beginners and experienced makers. This guide will help you make an informed decision.

## Overview

### Arduino
Arduino refers to both hardware boards and the development ecosystem. Popular boards include Uno, Nano, and Mega.

### ESP32
ESP32 is a system-on-chip (SoC) with integrated Wi-Fi and Bluetooth, offering powerful processing capabilities.

## Detailed Comparison

### Processing Power

**Arduino Uno (ATmega328P)**
- 8-bit microcontroller
- 16 MHz clock speed
- 32 KB flash memory
- 2 KB SRAM

**ESP32**
- 32-bit dual-core processor
- Up to 240 MHz clock speed
- 4 MB flash memory (typical)
- 520 KB SRAM

*Winner: ESP32* - Significantly more powerful

### Connectivity

**Arduino**
- No built-in wireless connectivity
- Requires additional shields/modules
- USB for programming
- Various communication protocols (I2C, SPI, UART)

**ESP32**
- Built-in Wi-Fi (802.11 b/g/n)
- Bluetooth 4.2 and BLE
- USB for programming
- Same communication protocols as Arduino

*Winner: ESP32* - Built-in wireless capabilities

### Power Consumption

**Arduino Uno**
- ~20 mA during operation
- ~15 mA in idle mode
- No built-in power management

**ESP32**
- ~160-240 mA during Wi-Fi operation
- ~20 mA in light sleep mode  
- ~2.5 A in deep sleep mode
- Advanced power management

*Winner: Arduino* - Lower baseline consumption, but ESP32 has better sleep modes

### GPIO and Peripherals

**Arduino Uno**
- 14 digital I/O pins
- 6 analog inputs
- 6 PWM outputs
- 1 UART, 1 SPI, 1 I2C

**ESP32**
- 34 GPIO pins (varies by board)
- 18 analog inputs (12-bit ADC)
- Multiple PWM channels
- 3 UART, 4 SPI, 2 I2C
- Touch sensors, Hall effect sensor

*Winner: ESP32* - More pins and peripherals

### Development Environment

**Arduino**
- Arduino IDE (simple and beginner-friendly)
- Extensive library support
- Large community
- Plenty of tutorials and examples

**ESP32**
- Arduino IDE support (ESP32 core)
- ESP-IDF (advanced development framework)
- MicroPython support
- Growing library ecosystem

*Winner: Arduino* - More mature ecosystem, but ESP32 is catching up

### Cost Comparison

**Arduino Uno**
- Official boards: $20-25
- Compatible boards: $5-15

**ESP32**
- Development boards: $5-15
- Module-only versions: $2-5

*Winner: ESP32* - Generally more affordable

### Use Case Scenarios

### When to Choose Arduino

1. **Learning Electronics**
   - Simpler to understand
   - Extensive educational resources
   - Less overwhelming for beginners

2. **Simple Projects**
   - Basic sensor reading
   - LED control
   - Motor control without wireless needs

3. **Real-time Applications**
   - Lower latency requirements
   - Predictable timing
   - Simple control loops

4. **Long Battery Life**
   - Projects requiring months/years of battery life
   - Minimal power consumption requirements

### When to Choose ESP32

1. **IoT Projects**
   - Need Wi-Fi or Bluetooth connectivity
   - Remote monitoring/control
   - Cloud integration

2. **Data-Intensive Applications**
   - Image processing
   - Complex algorithms
   - Multiple sensor fusion

3. **Web Servers**
   - Hosting web interfaces
   - REST APIs
   - Real-time dashboards

4. **Advanced Projects**
   - Machine learning inference
   - Audio processing
   - Complex automation systems

## Project Examples

### Arduino Projects
- Temperature logger with LCD
- Traffic light controller
- Servo motor control
- Simple robotics
- Home automation (no wireless)

### ESP32 Projects
- Weather station with web interface
- Smart home hub
- Security camera with notifications
- Bluetooth audio streamer
- GPS tracker with cloud logging

## Learning Path Recommendations

### For Beginners
1. Start with Arduino Uno
2. Learn basic programming concepts
3. Understand electronics fundamentals
4. Graduate to ESP32 for wireless projects

### For Intermediate Users
1. Choose based on project requirements
2. Arduino for simple, reliable projects
3. ESP32 for feature-rich applications

### For Advanced Users
1. Use ESP32 for most new projects
2. Arduino for specific use cases
3. Consider ESP32-S3 or ESP32-C3 variants

## Conclusion

Both platforms have their strengths:

**Choose Arduino if you:**
- Are new to electronics
- Need simple, reliable operation
- Want maximum battery life
- Don't need wireless connectivity

**Choose ESP32 if you:**
- Need Wi-Fi or Bluetooth
- Want more processing power
- Are building IoT applications
- Need cost-effective solutions

The best choice depends on your specific project requirements, experience level, and future expansion plans. Many makers eventually use both platforms for different types of projects.

Remember: There's no universal "better" choice  only the right choice for your specific needs.
    `}],Fh=["All","Basic Electronics","Arduino","ESP32","IoT","Tutorials","Comparison","Reviews"],Uh=()=>{const e=hn.slice(0,6),t=hn.filter(r=>r.views>1e3),n=wd.slice(0,3);return o.jsxs("div",{className:"min-h-screen",children:[o.jsx("section",{className:"bg-gradient-to-br from-blue-600 via-blue-700 to-indigo-800 text-white",children:o.jsx("div",{className:"max-w-7xl mx-auto px-4 sm:px-6 lg:px-8 py-20",children:o.jsxs("div",{className:"text-center",children:[o.jsx("div",{className:"flex justify-center mb-6",children:o.jsx("div",{className:"w-16 h-16 bg-white/10 rounded-full flex items-center justify-center backdrop-blur-sm",children:o.jsx(ws,{className:"w-8 h-8 text-yellow-400"})})}),o.jsx("h1",{className:"text-5xl md:text-6xl font-bold mb-6 leading-tight",children:"BLUEDOT ELECTRONICS"}),o.jsx("p",{className:"text-xl md:text-2xl mb-8 text-blue-100 max-w-3xl mx-auto",children:"Your Gateway to DIY Electronics & Innovation"}),o.jsx("p",{className:"text-lg mb-12 text-blue-200 max-w-2xl mx-auto",children:"Simplifying electronics for everyone, one project at a time. mb-8",children:o.jsxs("div",{className:"p-6",children:[o.jsx("h2",{className:"text-2xl font-bold text-gray-900 mb-4",children:"Circuit Diagram"}),o.jsx("img",{src:t.schematic,alt:"Circuit rounded-lg hover:bg-blue-700 transition-colors",children:[o.jsx(Yn,{className:"w-4 h-4"}),o.jsx("span",{children:"Download Schematic"})]})})]})}),o.jsx("div",{className:"bg-white rounded-lg shadow-md overflow-hidden mb-8",children:o.jsxs("div",{className:"p-6",children:[o.jsxs("div",{className:"flex items-center justify-between mb-4",children:[o.jsx("h2",{className:"text-2xl font-bold text-gray-900",children:"Arduino Code"}),o.jsxs("div",{className:"flex space-x-2",children:[o.jsxs("button",{className:"flex items-center space-x-2 bg-green-600 text-white px-4 py-2 rounded-lg hover:bg-green-700 transition-colors",children:[o.jsx(Yn,{className:"w-4 h-4"}),o.jsx("span",{children:"Download .ino"})]}),o.jsxs("button",{className:"flex items-center space-x-2 bg-gray-800 text-white px-4 py-2 rounded-lg hover:bg-gray-900 transition-colors",children:[o.jsx(ys,{className:"w-4 h-4"}),o.jsx("span",{children:"GitHub"})]})]})]}),o.jsx("pre",{className:"bg-gray-900 text-green-400 p-4 rounded-lg overflow-x-auto text-sm",children:o.jsx("code",{children:t.code})})]})}),o.jsx("div",{className:"bg-white rounded-lg shadow-md overflow-hidden mb-8",children:o.jsxs("div",{className:"p-6",children:[o.jsx("h2",{className:"text-2xl font-bold text-gray-900 mb-6",children:"Step-by-Step Instructions"}),o.jsx("div",{className:"space-y-4",children:t.instructions.map((r,l)=>o.jsxs("div",{className:"flex items-start space-x-4",children:[o.jsx("div",{className:"flex-shrink-0 w-8 h-8
